text: I got a really long error stack. I can't see the context and what the actual error was in the REPL. How should I make the REPL "longer" so I can scroll up more to see the error and the context of the error? I'm using VSCode if that matters

elements.text: I got a really long error stack. I can't see the context and what the actual error was in the REPL. How should I make the REPL "longer" so I can scroll up more to see the error and the context of the error? I'm using VSCode if that matters

text: Can we cross post this publicly to <https://discourse.julialang.org|Discourse> for further visibility? React with :bridge: on the message above to approve. <https://github.com/JuliaCommunity/SlackBridge/blob/main/README.md#faq|More info here>
I was able to `try`-`catch` the error and `println(e)`, but the context of why/where the error occured would be helpful

elements.text: I was able to
try
catch
the error and
println(e)
, but the context of why/where the error occured would be helpful

text: Success, it has been cross posted <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/57147| to Discourse>. Keep and eye out on Discourse for responses and please add an answer there once you are satisfied with the solution so others can benefit as well. Happy debugging!
By "using VSCode", do you mean you're running REPL on the integrated terminal?

elements.text: By "using VSCode", do you mean you're running REPL on the integrated terminal?

text: Yes that's exactly right!

elements.text: Yes that's exactly right!

text: VSCode allows you to resize the window of the terminal, right?

elements.text: VSCode allows you to resize the window of the terminal, right?

text: I think so. I resized the window and scrolled all the way up to the top of the REPL but I'm still not seeing all the way to the top of stacktrace

elements.text: I think so. I resized the window and scrolled all the way up to the top of the REPL but I'm still not seeing all the way to the top of stacktrace

text: Oh, right. I now understand what you're referring to, and I think that's just how VSCode is built - to replace the existing on-integrated terminal text once the max scroll limit is reached. You could just try running the REPL on a normal terminal session instead?

elements.text: Oh, right. I now understand what you're referring to, and I think that's just how VSCode is built - to replace the existing on-integrated terminal text once the max scroll limit is reached. You could just try running the REPL on a normal terminal session instead?

text: Oh I see! I didn't know that the limit was a VScode thing. I'll try to run in a normal terminal session

elements.text: Oh I see! I didn't know that the limit was a VScode thing. I'll try to run in a normal terminal session

text: Thank you!

elements.text: Thank you!

text: <@U01QRM4E8HL> It worked! I had to maximize and scroll way up but I got it! Would you like me to credit you posting the solution on Discourse? I can keep you anonymous, or put your initials or your name. Whatever you prefer

elements.text: It worked! I had to maximize and scroll way up but I got it! Would you like me to credit you posting the solution on Discourse? I can keep you anonymous, or put your initials or your name. Whatever you prefer

text: I wonder if that's possible

text: Good idea! I started looking into it and I think piping the stacktrace into a file should be possible by using StackTraces module and try-catch blocks to get the stacktrace info. Just not sure about the last step to pipe it into a file. Maybe something with print and file io <https://docs.julialang.org/en/v1/manual/stacktraces/|https://docs.julialang.org/en/v1/manual/stacktraces/>

elements.text: Good idea! I started looking into it and I think piping the stacktrace into a file should be possible by using StackTraces module and try-catch blocks to get the stacktrace info. Just not sure about the last step to pipe it into a file. Maybe something with print and file io
https://docs.julialang.org/en/v1/manual/stacktraces/

text: I haven't tested this idea, but I think I figured it out: using the stacktrace stuff with show(io::IO, _) to pipe it into a file

elements.text: I haven't tested this idea, but I think I figured it out: using the stacktrace stuff with show(io::IO, _) to pipe it into a file

text:
That is one way to do it, but it also requires you to know where the last stacktrace occured, no?

I was thinking some sort of repl feature that let you pipe the last printed stacktrace somewhere.

text:
```julia> stacktrace(catch_backtrace())
Base.StackTraces.StackFrame[]```
After I get a error stacktrace, the above just gives me an empty stack trace. Not sure how to get the most recent printed stacktrace without having to re-do the function call

elements.text:
julia> stacktrace(catch_backtrace())
Base.StackTraces.StackFrame[]
After I get a error stacktrace, the above just gives me an empty stack trace. Not sure how to get the most recent printed stacktrace without having to re-do the function call
